docs.abstract: Study released by Harvard and Princeton researchers suggests that only about one third of Americans consider obesity to be major public health problem, which could make it even harder for health authorities to wage battle against epidemic; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: With about one in four Americans obese, and nearly 60 percent over all considered overweight, it may be hard to imagine obesity as a hidden epidemic. But a study just released by researchers at Harvard and Princeton suggests that only about a third of Americans consider obesity to be a major public health problem.

headline.main: New Jersey? Bad Taste? Well Then, Don't Eat It.

docs.abstract: Debra Galant Jersey column on school project in which son and fourth-grade classmates assembled, decorated and ate gigantic cake shaped like New Jersey; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I read an article on the health of New Jerseyeans that said obesity had almost doubled in adults in the 1990's. The next day, in my son's school, the entire fourth grade assembled and ate a gigantic cake shaped like New Jersey. Though fighting my own battle against plumpness, I ate a piece representing farmland. Though it took less than five minutes to inhale it, the dense confection clogged my digestive tract for hours, like a rush hour smash-up on the Garden State Parkway.
